name: sfchronicle
text:
Phil Mickelson turned 50 in June and Tiger Woods will turn 45 in December. They still would command large crowds, if crowds were allowed, but popularity doesn‚Äôt translate to low scores. Golf doesn‚Äôt bow to reputation, writes @RonKroichick. 

https://t.co/mhRQTKx3WW

name: sfchronicle
text: As of Thursday there were nearly 70 reported cases of the coronavirus in the state‚Äôs three youth prisons ‚Äî or about 9% of the current population. More than a dozen staff had also tested positive for the virus. https://t.co/ZuLRbGLXXg

name: sfchronicle
text: Latino businesses have been hit particularly hard by the pandemic ‚Äî the number of Latino business owners whose firms were active dropped 43% from the beginning of February to the end of April, compared with a 19% drop in white owners of active businesses. https://t.co/y42sw1fDk5

name: sfchronicle
text: Hospitals in California are caring for 5,746 COVID-19 patients, continuing a downward trend, state officials reported. Of those hospitalized, 1,868 are in ICUs. Bay Area hospitalizations have also been trending down, standing at 663 patients on Friday. https://t.co/5QSt6VPc4l

name: sfchronicle
text: The challenge to reach these sites ‚Äî with hundreds available across national forests ‚Äî is a key to their appeal. https://t.co/WP52x8P6Wa

text:

Here are some answers and tips: https://t.co/nf75pYOxsI

name: sfchronicle
text:
Just two years ago, the idea of A's closer Liam Hendriks reaching the 500 strikeout mark seemed a stretch. But on Friday night against Houston, Hendriks reached the milestone.

https://t.co/fLJox0USVR

name: sfchronicle
text: Right now, during the pandemic, we‚Äôre all missing the social aspect of going to bars. But @Esther_Mobley is also missing things she never thought she‚Äôd miss. Like the dingy smells. https://t.co/g6eBokHa1s

name: sfchronicle
text:
Only a few S.F. Fire Department employees ‚Äî 3 out of 1,223 ‚Äî tested positive for coronavirus antibodies in a recent UCSF study, even though nearly half of those surveyed said they had likely or definitely been around people who were infected.

https://t.co/ojkHRvSK6o

name: sfchronicle
text:
Jes√∫s Luzardo‚Äôs outing Sunday might bear even more weight than his first start, coming as it does against the A‚Äôs top division rivals. And he made his big-league debut against the Astros last year, so he has good memories of facing Houston.

https://t.co/aTIl1yzwo8

name: sfchronicle
text:
Oakland police are investigating a shooting that killed one person on Saturday afternoon. Police released few details, but said officers responded near Lakeshore Avenue and Mandana Boulevard and found a male victim with a gunshot wound.

https://t.co/3mPPE7uoPx

name: sfchronicle
text:
PG&E must hire new tree-trimming supervisors, improve records about the age of risky electrical equipment and bolster the way it inspects high-voltage power lines under a recent order from a federal judge.

https://t.co/al7PSwOOju

name: sfchronicle
text:
A long-ball feast against Kershaw, a Cueto no-hitter lost in the night sky, Gabe Kapler's most questionable decision thus far, and a 5-4 Giants victory that evened their record against the Dodgers this season to 3-3.

@HankSchulman has the story: https://t.co/yR8p4koHTp

name: sfchronicle
text:

name: sfchronicle
text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
Vallejo police officers have killed 19 people since June 2010. No officers have been charged in connection.

Here's what you need to know about the department's history of killings, and the allegations of misconduct and abuse of people of color.

https://t.co/dEF1APZ9Gg

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/VL1ZlOlHgh

name: sfchronicle
text: Vallejo police officers accused of bending their badges to mark their killings may be immune from consequences because the city waited too long to investigate, according to legal experts and an attorney for the fired ex-captain who blew the whistle. https://t.co/xnQYcH68w8

name: sfchronicle
text:

text:

name: sfchronicle
text:
Herd immunity to the coronavirus is a tempting concept. But it is a dangerous goal that would sacrifice tens of thousands of lives nationwide, especially among people of color, public health experts say.

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: If you‚Äôre in San Francisco County and decide to attend a gathering of 25 people, there‚Äôs a 34% chance that someone who‚Äôs coronavirus-positive will be in attendance, new tool shows. https://t.co/vlE5bLALwi

name: sfchronicle
text: With the pandemic, economic inequalities have become more apparent, like who can and cannot access fast internet. The answer? Make it public, @GregRThomas writes: https://t.co/vvBvkitMpi

name: sfchronicle
text: Are we on the verge of virus-sensing implants and virtual hamster balls? Futurist @psaffo tells us which inventions are on the horizon and what will remain as sci-fi stories. https://t.co/pe5A20PfSV https://t.co/jPnTsMKrZD

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúThe good thing about the cash is we don‚Äôt have to succumb to Grubhub.‚Äù Nino and Kim Hernandez of Ramiro & Sons Taqueria fear one day, the convenience of apps may end their family‚Äôs burrito legacy: https://t.co/vVgmn0LcE8

name: sfchronicle
text: What does 2022 look like? Meetings, meetings and more meetings. Through screens, of course. @EmilyDreyfuss imagines daily life here: https://t.co/VtxXtsG3de

name: sfchronicle
text: Since the 1990s, Stanford professor Byron Reeves has been watching the way people watch screens. Now, during the pandemic, he shares predictions on our digital activity, with life becoming more "mediatized."  https://t.co/PYJPcKDO88

name: sfchronicle
text: Yearning for touch and basic human contact, designer Amara reflects on the AI and what it means for people of color in this short story set in S.F.: https://t.co/wINpeNKbC5
